sub_concepts.name: Clustering
sub_concepts.definition: A method of grouping distributed systems together to provide a single system with increased performance and availability.

sub_concepts.name: Load balancing
sub_concepts.definition: The distribution of workloads across multiple computing resources, such as servers, to ensure no single resource becomes overwhelmed.

sub_concepts.name: Data replication
sub_concepts.definition: The process of storing the same data in multiple locations to ensure availability and consistency in the event of a failure.

sub_concepts.name: Transparent failover
sub_concepts.definition: The ability for a distributed system to automatically switch to a backup system in the event of a failure, with no disruption to the user.

sub_concepts.name: Concurrency control
sub_concepts.definition: The management of simultaneous access to shared resources in a distributed system to prevent conflicts and maintain consistency.

sub_concepts.name: Fault tolerance
sub_concepts.definition: The ability of a distributed system to continue operating in the event of a failure, such as the loss of a single node or network link.

sub_concepts.name: Distributed file systems
sub_concepts.definition: A file system that allows multiple computers to access and share files over a network as if they were on a local disk.

sub_concepts.name: Distributed databases
sub_concepts.definition: A database that is spread across multiple computers, allowing for increased scalability and availability.

sub_concepts.name: Message passing
sub_concepts.definition: A communication method in distributed systems where processes communicate by sending and receiving messages.

sub_concepts.name: Remote procedure call (RPC)
sub_concepts.definition: A technique for implementing client-server communication in distributed systems, where a procedure call made by a client appears to be a local procedure call.
